title: Factory worker who severed hand with meat slicer can move fingers again
text:
Warning: Graphic Images

Lawrence Cooper is optimisitc about regaining full use of his hand (Picture: 9 News/Mater Hospital)

A man who cut his hand off with a meat slicer at work can move his fingers again thanks to ‘miraculous’ reattachment surgery.

Lawrence ‘Lorry’ Cooper, 23, is on the road to recovery after making the life-changing mistake during his factory shift.

He says he feels ‘grateful’ doctors were able to save his hand, which had been severed below his thumb.

The surgeons who treated him said successfully re-attaching a whole hand is rare, with lots of room for things to go horribly wrong.

Lawrence said he ‘only remembers glimpses’ of the incident which left him feeling a unbearable ‘phantom pain’ – which can still be felt even when a limb is no longer there.

He could move his fingers just a day after an intense operation (Picture: 9 News)

Luckily a quick thinking workmate put the severed hand in ice and tied a tourniquet around his arm to try and stem the bleeding.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Lawrence was then rushed to Mater Private Hospital in Brisbane, Australia, in August for treatment from a team of plastic and reconstructive surgeons.

Doctors were under pressure to reconnect the blood supply to the hand in time.

They said an artery cannot be sewn together straight away because it is too flimsy.

Dr Theo Birch told ABC Australia: ‘You need to plate and screw the bones together, repair the deeper tendons — only then is it safe to focus on the fine microvascular surgery.’

Doctors had to start by reattaching the bone and deeper tendons before working on arteries (Picture: Mater Hospital)

Surgeons said the fact his hand was cut off so cleanly made things easier (Picture: Mater Hospital)

The team said the process was made easier because his amputation was so clean – probably because it was done by a meat slicer.

None of the severed bones were jagged, making it much more simple for doctors to attach them.

Working from the inside out, surgeons spent seven hours working meticulously to save Lawrence’s hand and kept him monitored in intensive care for several hours afterwards.

Just a small clot in any of the reattached blood vessels could have cut off the circulation.

The surgeons who worked on him said re-attaching a whole hand is rare (Picture: Mater Hospital)

He is still on the long road to recovery but doctors say his progress is ‘promising’

Doctors said it was ‘miraculous’ and ‘promising’ that Lawrence was able to move his fingers just a day later.

But Dr Birch warned severed nerves grow back ‘very slowly’ and are the ‘most unpredictable’ part of the recovery process.

Optimisitc of eventually regaining full use of his hand, Lawrence said: ‘You’re always grateful and you’re always happy but there’s a lot of mental issues.

‘I think you’ve just got to be strong-willed. It’s just about seeing how it progresses.’

description: A man who sliced off his hand can move his fingers again after being operated on by surgeons at Mater Private Hospital, Brisbane, Australia.
